awd_titl_txt: Mentoring and Engaging Computer Science, Cybersecurity, and Bioinformatics Students to Increase Their Recruitment, Retention, and Preparation for the Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
In response to high workforce demands in the areas of computer science, cybersecurity, and bioinformatics, the project team for this "NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM) Capacity Building" project at Fontbonne University will work closely with industry contacts to ensure that (1) Fontbonne's degree programs meet local needs in the St. Louis area as well as address national workforce needs and (2) low-income, academically talented students will be equipped to enter these careers by providing scholarships, academic, and career supports for its S-STEM Scholars. The project will concentrate on increasing enrollment, retention, graduation, and placement of diverse, low-income students in these focal areas. To foster this, the project will provide eleven scholarships, mentoring, skills for transitioning to college-level mathematics, undergraduate research and internship opportunities, real-world project-based learning, a summer orientation program, and a seminar series on information technology (IT) project management. In concert with this, strong industry connections will partner with the institution on the seminar series, internship opportunities, serving on advisory boards, and student mentoring to help promote and facilitate computer science, cybersecurity, and bioinformatics careers and/or entry into graduate school in these arenas.

A fundamental goal of the project is to investigate the effects and challenges of a model for student success in experiential learning that includes: (a) engagement of industry in providing internships and developing real-world applications for project-based learning; (b) a summer orientation program to teach incoming students how to learn mathematics in subsequent courses; (c) seminars with industry input in project management; and (d) the implementation of faculty mentoring and cohort supports. Objectives include: enrolling eleven new S-STEM Scholars who are low-income, academically talented, and majoring in computer science, cybersecurity, or bioinformatics; graduating at least nine of the scholars in four years; and having all graduating scholars either employed in their field or attending graduate school within six months of graduation. To research and assess the impact of the various strategies, individually and cumulatively, the project team will use a qualitative and quantitative mixed-methods research and evaluation approach in connection with investigating a variety of variables including financial support, the orientation program and project management seminar, professional guidance and mentoring, and overall impact of industry influence and involvement. The research approach will allow the investigators to measure the success of their strategies, particularly concerning extensive and gauged interactions with industry. The research and evaluation will generate evidence that can be used to guide and inform sustained programming and transferability to other institutions, especially in urban areas.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF Goal 1: To increase student recruitment, retention, student success, and graduation rates.

 

NSF Goal 2: To implement and study models, effective practices, and/or strategies that contribute to understanding the factors of supportive curricular and co-curricular activities that affect student recruitment, retention, student success, academic/career pathways, and/or degree attainment.

 

NSF Goal 3: To contribute to the implementation and sustainability of effective curricular and co-curricular activities supporting these students.

 

Four Objectives of the grant project submitted by Fontbonne University.

 

  1. Increased Enrollment. METS-S will enroll 11 scholars over a five-year grant period (two cohorts of six and five, respectively) who are low-income, academically talented, and who will major in computer science, cybersecurity or bioinformatics.  In 2014, nine freshmen and four transfers entered those majors.  Addresses NSF Goal 1.

 

  1. Improved retention and graduation. Ten of 11 METS-S scholars will be retained until their second year, and at least nine will graduate in their major within four years (insufficient data are available to ascertain baseline first-year retention and four-year graduation rates. Addresses NSF Goals 1, 2, and 3.

 

  1. Placement. 100 % of the graduating METS-S scholars will be employed in their field or will attend graduate school in a related STEM field within six months of graduation. Addresses NSF Goal 2.

 

  1. Institutionalization and sustainability. By the end of the grant period, the department will realize sustained growth in students participating in industry-based research or internships and will have increased the number of members on its computer science and cybersecurity industry advisory board from the current six members to at least 10.  A new bioinformatics advisory board will be formed and operational.  Addresses NSF Goals 2 and 3.

 

What was accomplished under these goals (you must provide information for at least one of the 4 categories below)?

NSF Goal 1

Major Activities:

 

Prior to fall 2019, each STEM scholar met (minimally) with his/her academic advisor two times and met with Dr. Abkemeier (PI) once. At each meeting, not only were academic matters discussed, but also student engagement at Fontbonne, off-campus work, and other topics were discussed.  Due to the pandemic, no meetings were held in spring 2020, fall 2020 or spring 2021.

 

The students did not keep a journal of their activities from spring 2020 through spring 2021 due to the pandemic.

 

The Department of Mathematics and Computer Science hosts three student clubs: Math/CS, ACM (student), and a Hacker's Club.   No meetings nor events took place from spring 2020 through spring 2021.

 

Fontbonne continues to be a member of the Gateway Higher Education Cybersecurity Consortium (GHECC).  PI Abkemeier is on the Executive Committee, and her Dean is President of the Board of Directors.  

 

Specific Objectives:  Fontbonne Objectives 1 and 2

 

Significant Results:  

At the beginning of the 2020/21 academic year there were five students in Cohort 1.  Of the five four graduated in May 2021.  The second cohort’s graduation rate was low with four of the five becoming inactive due to a variety of circumstances.  By the end of the grant Fontbonne awarded funding to 31 students.  Ten received funding for only one year.

 

Key outcomes or other achievements: six STEM scholars will continue as students in one of these two majors: Cybersecurity (3), Computer Science (3).   

 

NSF Goal 3

Major Activities

 

One new advisory board member was added to the computer science/cybersecurity advisory board during the 2020/21 academic year.  His areas of expertise are cybersecurity and analytics. Two retired with one of the retires being appointed the Fontbonne Board of Trustees.  The total number of board members is now nine.

 

Fontbonne removed the BS in Bioinformatics starting in fall 2020 due to low enrollment. It was replaced with a BS in Data Science. 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2022
Modified by: Mary Abkemeier
